articles.headline: Government Reconsiders Quick Sale of Citigroup Stake
articles.snippet: Two days after Citigroup moved to untangle itself from Washington, the Treasury backed away from plans to immediately sell a portion of its stake in the bank, according to a person briefed on the situation.
articles.abstract: Two days after Citigroup moved to untangle itself from Washington, the Treasury backed away from plans to immediately sell a portion of its stake in the bank, according to a person briefed on the situation.
articles.lead_paragraph: Just when Vikram S. Pandit thought he was out, Washington is pulling him back in.

articles.headline: Claims of Insider Trading From Trader’s Ex-Wife
articles.snippet: This is a story about money and marriage on Wall Street, about a fugitive, a billionaire, an ex-wife and her lawsuit.
articles.abstract: This is a story about money and marriage on Wall Street, about a fugitive, a billionaire, an ex-wife and her lawsuit.
articles.lead_paragraph: This is a story about money and marriage on Wall Street  one about a fugitive, a billionaire, an ex-wife and her lawsuit.
articles.byline: By Jenny Anderson and Zachery Kouwe

articles.headline: Getting Fit With 2 Bits of Help
articles.snippet: Two new wearable motion sensors are available to monitor your physical activity and provide feedback.
articles.abstract: Two new wearable motion sensors are available to monitor your physical activity and provide feedback.
articles.lead_paragraph: I’d like to talk about New Year’s resolutions for a minute.

articles.headline: Pakistan Reported to Be Harassing U.S. Diplomats
articles.snippet: In what U.S. officials describe as a concerted effort, frequent car searches and the denial of visas have disrupted embassy work.
articles.abstract: In what U.S. officials describe as a concerted effort, frequent car searches and the denial of visas have disrupted embassy work.
articles.lead_paragraph: ISLAMABAD, Pakistan  Parts of the Pakistani military and intelligence services are mounting what American officials here describe as a campaign to harass American diplomats, fraying relations at a critical moment when the Obama administration is demanding more help to fight the Taliban and Al Qaeda.
articles.byline: By Jane Perlez and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Bank Picks a Successor to Lewis
articles.snippet: Bank of America named one of its top managers, Brian Moynihan, as its chief executive, succeeding Kenneth D. Lewis, who plans to leave by the end of the year.
articles.abstract: Bank of America named one of its top managers, Brian Moynihan, as its chief executive, succeeding Kenneth D. Lewis, who plans to leave by the end of the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Finally, there is white smoke at Bank of America: Brian T. Moynihan was selected to become the next chief executive.
articles.byline: By Eric Dash and Louise Story

articles.headline: That Tap Water Is Legal but May Be Unhealthy
articles.snippet: The federal law regulating tap water is so out of date that the water Americans drink can pose serious health risks.
articles.abstract: The federal law regulating tap water is so out of date that the water Americans drink can pose serious health risks.
articles.lead_paragraph: The 35-year-old federal law regulating tap water is so out of date that the water Americans drink can pose what scientists say are serious health risks  and still be legal.

articles.headline: U.N. Officials Say American Offered Plan to Replace Karzai
articles.snippet: As fraud surfaced in the Afghan election, the No. 2 U.N. official in the country proposed enlisting the White House in a plan to replace Hamid Karzai.
articles.abstract: As fraud surfaced in the Afghan election, the No. 2 U.N. official in the country proposed enlisting the White House in a plan to replace Hamid Karzai.
articles.lead_paragraph: As widespread fraud in the Afghanistan presidential election was becoming clear three months ago, the No. 2 United Nations official in the country, the American Peter W. Galbraith, proposed enlisting the White House in a plan to replace the Afghan president, Hamid Karzai, according to two senior United Nations officials.
articles.byline: By James Glanz and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: 4 Big Mortgage Backers Swim in Ocean of Debt
articles.snippet: There is a risk of a debt loop, as the companies draw new government money to keep up with their existing debts.
articles.abstract: There is a risk of a debt loop, as the companies draw new government money to keep up with their existing debts.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as the biggest banks repay their government debt in what is being heralded as a successful rescue program, four troubled giants of the financial world remain on government life support.

articles.headline: Accenture, as if Tiger Woods Were Never There
articles.snippet: For a company that has spent millions to link its services with Woods’s image, severing that link may take time.
articles.abstract: For a company that has spent millions to link its services with Woods’s image, severing that link may take time.
articles.lead_paragraph: How do you Tiger-proof an entire corporation? At Accenture, you start by telling employees to tear down all the posters that say, now somewhat awkwardly, that “we know what it takes to be a Tiger.”
